thread.title: Funeral details announced for Super Garden winner John Dooley
thread.title_full: Funeral details announced for Super Garden winner John Dooley

author: VNExplorer
title: Funeral details announced for Super Garden winner John Dooley
text: The funeral of RTÉ Super Garden winner John Dooley will take place on Saturday, June 8. The Kildare man passed away suddenly on June 5 after making his 'dream come true' by winning RTÉ's Super Garden competition as well as getting to showcase his garden at the prestigious Bord Bia Bloom Garden Festival. Today's top videos His death notice on RIP.ie reads: 'Deeply regretted by his loving wife Liz, brothers, sisters, sister-in-law, brothers-in-law, nieces, relatives, neighbours and a large circle of friends.' Liz and John Dooley in his 'Back to the Future' garden on Super Garden. Pic: RTÉ John's remains will repose in Dunne's Funeral Home on Mill Road in Castledermot, Co Kildare on Friday, June 7 from noon, concluding with rosary at 8pm. His remains will be removed to The Church of the Assumption of Castledermot at 11.30am on Saturday, June 8 for his funeral mass at noon. This will be followed by burial in Coltstown Cemetery. John Dooley (centre) with Gary Hegarty, Breda Tennyson, Dijana Kalic and Pedro Roche on Super Garden. Pic: RTÉ Brian beat out stiff competition from the other budding gardeners on RTÉ's Super Garden, wowing judges Brian Burke, Monica Alvarez, and Carol Marks with his Back To The Future garden. Speaking after being named the winner of the series, John told the broadcaster that he was shocked when he learned that his wife had secretly signed him up for the show after he shared his desire to exhibit his work at Bloom a couple of years earlier. Super Garden winner John Dooley. Pic: RTÉ 'I said to Liz, I was glad she did it because if we had spoken about it first I would have said "no way, I wouldn't have been able for it,"' John continued at the time. 'But when she put me in I was in shock first but then I said, "we'll give it a go and see".' 'It was stressful in the lead-up to it, but once we were two days into it we just totally enjoyed it. Had a ball,' he told RTÉ.
